page.title: 15POLWARTH VILLAGE & THORNS
page.content: POLWARTH VILLAGE WAS ONCE A VERY FLOURISHING CENTRE. THE NAME COMES FROM THE GAELIC 'POL' & CAMBRO BRITISH 'PUL' MEANING MUDDY STREAM & THE SAXON 'WARTH' OR 'WORTH' MEANING SMALL VILLAGE OR FARMSTEAD.IN THE EARLY 19 CENTURY THERE WERE 228 INHABITANTS IN THE THATCHED COTTAGES SCATTERED ROUND THE GREEN, THE REMAINS OF WHICH CAN STILL BE SEEN. NOW THE ONLY INHABITED HOUSES ARE THE SCHOOL HOUSE WHICH SHUT AS A SCHOOL IN 1964, THE OLDER SCHOOL & THE FARMHOUSE OF POLWARTH CROFTS. THE POLWARTH THORNS ARE IN THE MIDDLE OF THE GREEN. THE OLDER ONE IS PROPPED UP BUT THE YOUNGER IS GROWING. 'POLWATH ON THE GREEN' BY THE 18 CENTURY POET ALLAN RAMSAY IMMORTALIZED AN OLDER SONG & THE CUSTOM OF DANCING ROUND THE TORNS AT WEDDINGS PERSISTED FOR OVER 300 YEARS.THE LAST KNOWN OCCASION BEING IN 1804
